item.title: 6 Models of The Modern Data Center
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Information Week
By: Charles Babcock and Chris Murphy
6/2/2014
The cloud hasn't killed the company-owned data center. Companies from General Motors to Fidelity are taking the best infrastructure ideas from Web giants such as Facebook and Google and adapting them to their very different business needs in order to build a new generation of data centers. To highlight the different approaches and strategies these companies are taking, we looked at six companies beyond the Web giants that have made or are planning major data center investments. Our point isn't that data center construction is booming; Gartner forecasts only 2.3% growth in data center spending in 2014, to $143 billion. Companies will spend more than twice that on enterprise software, by comparison, at a growth rate of nearly 7%. But we are seeing a boom in data center innovation, and it's coming not just from Web and cloud service companies, but from conventional companies that still see running world-class data centers as part of their competitive advantage. Here's an overview of the innovations that we'll explore in this slideshow: Fidelity is opening a new data center in Nebraska this fall. The investment giant is one of the biggest advocates outside Silicon Valley for open source hardware, and the new building itself is a modular, just-in-time construction design. General Motors spent $130 million on a new data center in Michigan, with a second one coming online this summer. It's a private-cloud-meets-mainframe operation, as the company supports both Web-ready apps and long-running legacy software. Capital One christened its new $150 million Virginia facility in March, replacing capacity by third-party operators as the company shifts from an outsourcing strategy to insourcing most of its IT. The goal is to make sure infrastructure doesn't slow down its new Agile development initiatives.
To view the full article click here. To read about Capital One click here.
item.excerpt:encoded: Our exclusive look inside the new data centers of Fidelity, GM, Capital One, Equinix, ServiceNow, and Bank Of America shows the future of computing.

item.title: Isabel Bader Centre Celebrates Grand Opening
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Queen's Journal
By: Lauren Luchenski
9/22/2014
After nearly a decade of planning and construction, the Isabel Bader Centre for the Performing Arts celebrated its grand opening this past weekend. On Sept. 20, members of the Queen’s and Kingston community gathered at the waterfront venue located on King St. for the new centre’s official ribbon cutting. The building was inspired by the lead donors, Drs. Alfred and Isabel Bader. It was designed in a collaborative effort by Snøhetta Design Architects and N45 Architecture. Following a bagpipe procession and traditional Mohawk opening by Aboriginal Council Co-Chair Marlene Brant Castellano, drama professor Tim Fort led the events as Master of Ceremonies. Remarks were given by Principal Daniel Woolf, Kingston and the Islands MPP Sophie Kiwala, Mayor Mark Gerretsen, Snøhetta architect Craig Dykers and Board of Trustees chair Barbara Palk. Afterwards, the group of distinguished community members cut the bright purple ribbon alongside the Baders. The final product of Queen’s newest building has been much anticipated since its groundbreaking on Oct. 1, 2009. Construction was originally scheduled to begin in spring 2011, but was delayed until spring 2012 due to heritage concerns. Alfred Bader donated a total of $31 million towards the building, which cost $72 million to build. Approximately $30 million came from the provincial and federal governments, $6 million was donated by the City of Kingston and the remaining $5 million was raised by the University. Isabel Bader said she hopes her vision for the appreciation of the fine art world will reach many. “I hope [the centre] is for Queen’s and Kingston. I hope it’s for a much wider audience than that,” she said. With Kingston’s existing art facilities, such as Modern Fuel Artist-Run Centre and the Agnes Etherington Art Centre, Principal Woolf anticipates that Dr. Bader’s hopes will come true. “In balance with those existing facilities, Kingston could really become a hub for the fine arts,” Woolf said. “We’re going to get performers here that probably wouldn’t have come to Kingston otherwise and that’s going to be a benefit to the community. Not just a cultural benefit, but I think there’s economic potential there as well.” Principal Woolf also said he foresees stronger relationships between the varying fine arts disciplines – drama, film and media, fine arts and music – at Queen’s. “I think it’s going to be a great opportunity for interdisciplinary collaboration between all the fine arts,” Woolf said. He added that he hopes the new building will attract students to attend the fine arts degree program at Queen’s. “In the era of student tours, the buildings make a difference,” Woolf said. “Students will come here, see this and say, ‘I can perform here’.” The Journal reported last week that students were upset over a lack of accessibility to the facility, as well as a shortage of food options. Despite this, students who spoke at the opening touched on the “magnificence” of the building. In comparison to the facilities available to fine arts students prior to the Isabel, music student Daphne Kennedy said this is a major upgrade. “You can’t even really compare – it’s a whole new world here,” Kennedy, ArtSci ‘16, said. Kennedy, as well as other fine arts students, said she’s aware of the opportunities the facility is presenting for them. “Being able to bring world-class artists here is going to be incredible. It will be a huge inspiration for us all,” she said. To view full article click here.

item.title: Isabel Bader Centre for the Performing Arts: an Exceptional Building Completed Under Exceptional Circumstances
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Construction Dive
10/2/2014
The Isabel Bader Centre for the Performing Arts at Queen’s University celebrated its grand opening September 20, 2014. Queen’s University hired Mark G. Anderson Consultants (MGAC) as their owner’s representative in September of 2012, four months after construction started. Queen’s University selected MGAC over seven other firms. Construction finished on time thanks to uncommon levels of cooperation among the project team. The Isabel will be a home for the creative arts at Queen’s University and a hub of vibrant artistic study, creation and exhibition in the Kingston community. MGAC reconceived the initial project plan to meet the Queen’s University vision for the project and bring in the project under budget. MGAC staff created and monitored a realistic timeline and financial plan that detailed project goals for the entire team and created a shared path to project success. MGAC also worked with the City of Kingston, which was renovating the historical J.K. Tett Building in an overlapping construction zone. This sort of collaboration was typical of the project: “Right up to substantial completion, the entire project team worked together in an unprecedented way to have a world-class concert hall and quality building on time,” Michael Grey, Managing Director-Vice President of MGAC Canada said. Two project leaders met and solved issues regularly at an ordinary cafe—the meetings themselves, however, were extraordinary. Michael Grey of MGAC, the Queen’s University representative met routinely with the general contractor’s project manager as part of the Isabel project’s exceptional collaboration. Together Grey and the general contractor’s project manager drank coffee, solved existing problems, and look ahead at upcoming challenges—an unusual alliance for the construction world. These informal meetings kept the Isabel construction on schedule and avoided the spiral of disputes and negotiations formal requests can cause.

item.title: Renaissance Jaragua Santo Domingo Begins $30M Renovation
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Hotel Business
8/5/2014
SANTO DOMINGO, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC—Renaissance Jaragua Santo Domingo Hotel has begun a one-year, $30-million renovation of its historic hotel. In addition to giving all of the 300 guestrooms of the Santo Domingo hotel a completely new interior that incorporates a fresh color schedule and modern furnishings, the restoration plans will include new meeting and event space, restaurants, guest common spaces and lobby. The design of the renovation was inspired by both Santo Domingo’s tropical location and modern design. The renovated guestrooms will feature a color palette of silvers, honey-colored woods and yellows. The Renaissance Santo Domingo Jaragua Hotel and Casino renovations will also feature a new ballroom, restaurants and meeting spaces. The meeting spaces and ballroom will showcase a “fountains of light” design—a focus on colorful lighting paired with simplistic nudes and silvers—as the focal point of the new rooms, according to the brand. Renaissance Jaragua Santo Domingo first opened in 1942. The Santo Domingo Hotel is located directly on the Malecon along the Santo Domingo coastline.

item.title: Which President Loved Squirrel Soup? New White House Visitor Center Tells All
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Washington Post
By Michael E. Ruane
9/9/2014

First lady Grace Coolidge kept a pet raccoon on the grounds.

President Harry S. Truman installed a bowling alley inside. President Chester A. Arthur wanted to tear the building down. The White House: Venerable home to U.S. presidents. Symbol of the nation’s continuity. One of the world’s most famous dwellings. But it is also a place of children, weddings and farewells; of pets, card games and TV dinners; and the occasional upset or scandal. On Wednesday, first lady Michelle Obama is scheduled to attend the ribbon-cutting at the White House Visitor Center, which reopens to the public Saturday after a two-year hiatus for a $12.6 million renovation. The center, on Pennsylvania Avenue just east of 15th Street NW, is designed to give visitors, with or without an official White House tour, a sense of the history and lore of the building that has been the president’s house for more than 200 years. Admission is free, and the center will be open from 7:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. all year except for Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year’s Day.

The National Park Service, which operates the center, and the White House Historical Association, which chipped in $7.5 million for the renovation, have filled the center with White House and presidential memorabilia, much of it never displayed before.

The Civil War telegraph key used to respond to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant’s message announcing that Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee had surrendered at Appomattox Court House is there. The green Hammond Multiplex portable typewriter President Woodrow Wilson used in 1919 while touring the country to drum up support for the League of Nations is there. The big wooden desk that President Franklin D. Roosevelt used to deliver his famous “fireside chats” on the radio is there, in front of a blowup photo of FDR sitting at the desk. There are also scads of interactive features and virtual views of the house, its rooms and furnishings down through the years. One hands-on quiz displays servings of simulated foods that were presidential favorites and asks which food was especially liked by which president. Jelly beans? Ronald Reagan. Rice pudding? Grant. Squirrel soup? James A. Garfield. The center also displays copies of some of the powerful letters and telegrams received by presidents. In 1958, Jackie Robinson, who broke major league baseball’s color barrier,wrote a stern letter to President Dwight D. Eisenhower after listening to him speak on race. “You said we must have patience,” Robinson wrote. “I respectfully remind you sir that we have been the most patient of all people. . . . You unwittingly crush the spirit of freedom in Negroes by constantly urging forbearance.” There’s a moving telegram.

On Feb. 23, 1942, among the darkest days of World War II, FDR told the country in a fireside chat: “Your government has unmistakable confidence in your ability to hear the worst, without flinching or losing heart.” That same day, in Bridgeport, Conn., a person named J.B. Manual wired the president: “Just heard your speech. It cheered me up. Received notice today that my son was killed . . . at Pearl Harbor December 7.”

The visitor center was established in 1995 in Malcolm Baldridge Hall, the ornate old Patent Search Office in the Commerce Department building. There, visitors could pick up White House tour tickets and see some modest exhibits. But since the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, tour tickets have only been given out through members of Congress or foreign embassies. The need for the visitors center was diminished, said Stewart D. McLaurin, president of the White House Historical Association. But experts saw an opportunity to expand and enhance the center. “For people who did get to go to the White House, we could give them a more enriching experience,” McLaurin said at the center Monday. “For those who don’t have the opportunity to go to the White House, it is as good as you’re going to get to have an understanding of the [White House] as office, home and ceremonial stage,” he said. Many of the artifacts have been acquired over the years by the association, which was started by first lady Jacqueline Kennedy in 1961, he said. Most are stored at a Park Service facility in Maryland when not on display. “I think that the galleries here and the exhibits here are on par with any presidential library and most galleries at the Smithsonian,” McLaurin said. There’s also a film about life inside the White House, a bookstore, and pictures of Grace Coolidge and her pet raccoon, Rebecca, and of President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, dining on TV tables. Among the more striking images are the designs for an altered White House. When Congress declined to fund Arthur’s plan to tear down the White House and rebuild it in the 1880s, he developed a proposal to erect a garishprivate residence right next door.

Two administrations later, first lady Caroline Harrison found the White House too small and crowded for the 11 members of her family living there, and planned on huge wings that dwarfed the executive mansion.

Neither plan came to fruition. Near the center of the exhibit hall is the gilded copper eagle, now somewhat weathered, that watched almost a century of history from the top of the White House flagpole from 1898 to 1993. “If you’ve lived here, and you’ve been to the White House a lot . . . or if you’ve never been to the White House, this is the kind of place that would give you a real insightful understanding,” McLaurin said of the center.

Despite her husband’s turbulent presidency, Julia Dent Grant maintained an affection for the dwelling that she made the center of Washington society and home for her four children for eight years.

“I love the dear old house,” she said. For original article click here.

item.title: Grand Cayman Marriott Beach Resort Completes $16M Reno
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Hotel Business
12/8/2014
Grand Cayman Marriott Beach Resort, located on the Caribbean island's Seven Mile Beach, recently completed a renovation totaling more than $16 million. In phase two of the renovation, all public areas of the Grand Cayman resort have undergone a major transformation, including the lobby, restaurants, ballroom, meeting rooms and fitness center. The ground floor arrival, lobby, bar and dining spaces were designed by EDG Interior Architecture + Design. The inspiration for the new design embraces a ship-to-shore concept that embodies the themes of the spirit of openness, sense of adventure, craftsmanship and the island's strong connection with the sea, according to the resort. The resort's guestrooms were overhauled last year with phase one of the renovation. The choice of the furnishings' color palette reinforces the use of natural light. There is an emphasis on neutral and light colors such as white, beige and tones of gray. Different shades of blue have been incorporated to remind guests of the sea. Different textures such as polished wood, leather and weaved fabrics for the furniture creates fun, modern but comfortable seating arrangements for guests, according to the resort. Wood is featured heavily within the fixtures. Central to the renovation is also the rebranding of the lobby, restaurant and bar into Anchor & Den. Alfresco dining is offered at the newly revamped oceanfront restaurant and bar. Renamed Veranda and Vista Bar, the space features vintage-inspired decor. As part of the resort's services, amenities include free Linus bike rentals and complimentary snorkeling gear, which guests can use to explore the Artificial Reef Project, a short swim from the hotel's beachfront. item.title: Fits & Bursts | The Isabel: The Perilous Life of a Newborn Concert Hall
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Musical Toronto
By: Michael Vincent
9/15/2014
Congratulations it’s a girl! Named the Isabel Bader Centre for the Performing Arts, the multidisciplinary complex is housed overlooking the shores of Lake Ontario, on what was once a brewery and military hospital. After seven years of planning, it’s finally ready to unveil itself during Isabel’s inaugural season opener, September, 21st 2014. The multidisciplinary space was commissioned by Queen’s University as a means to showcase not only student work, but also world-class talent. “The need for a ‘proper’ concert hall in Kingston has been discussed for decades and finally in 2014 we have a hall to call our own,” writes former Director, Jerry Doiron, who programmed the first season. The concept behind the space is a kind of multidisciplinary Swiss army knife, which can accommodate both teaching and public concerts, as well as provide exhibition space for the Queen’s School of Music, the Department of Drama, Department of Film and Media, and the Bachelor of Fine Arts program. The structure claims an adaptable 100-seat blackbox studio theatre, a specialised film screening room, a large flat floor music rehearsal room, production studio, film edit suites, art gallery and teaching seminar rooms. The crown jewel of The Isabel is the 500-seat concert hall, which flaunts an impressive –N1– acoustic rating, making it an ideal space for the most delicate classical music performances, in any context. It also features distinctive acoustic drapery that can be adapted with a flick of a switch to suit the needs of chamber groups, orchestras and rock bands. Behind the Isabel’s blue-ribbon acoustics is the US-based ARUP acoustics and audio-visual consulting firm, who designed the hall (in its natural state) for small to mid-sized chamber classical music. The field of architectural acoustics trace back over 100 years with Wallace Sabine (1868-1919), who is widely considered to be the father of modern acoustics. “There were also Roman texts on acoustics, and the Greeks also did amazing work on the subject. If you look at their Epidaurus and their amphitheatres, it was known that people had learned from precedent of what worked, and what didn’t work, but as a modern field of science, it is basically over 100 years old,” says Stoway. Stoway and his partner Matt Mahon have been working on the project since its inception in 2007. Based in New York City, they have been a part of many high-profile projects, including the Oslo Opera House, the World Trade Centre Pavilion, the second Avenue Subway system in Manhattan and the 2,100-seat Maison symphonique de Montréal. They have also worked with a number of sound artists , and art gallery sound installation projects. They began collaborating on the design process alongside the Norwegian firm Snøhetta, and Ottawa-based N45 architects – first meeting with faculty and staff from Queen’s University, who were impressed with ARUP’s vision and reputation for creating pristine acoustical environments. “We sat down with [Queen's] film and drama and the music faculty in early 2008 and asked, what is this room going to be used for, and how many performances it’s going to have? From that we derived what size the room needs to be to acoustically make it work,” Solway said. “After blocking out the space, we further refined the plans in a totally collaborative process.” They used a special 3D design modeling program to map out the proposed design specifications into a virtual acoustic space, that gave them the ability to listen to the concert hall before it was even built. “…We developed a space we call the Sound Lab, and it’s a room where we can recreate the acoustics of spaces we are designing or what we’ve gone and measured,” explains Solway. “It’s a visually immersive aural environment.” […] “What was key to our approach is that we like to model through listening.” They also made a mockup of the concert hall using 24 of the actual seats used in the space in the controlled environment of their advanced acoustics lab.  “…Seats and people are the main absorbing elements in a room, so we measured that in an acoustic test lab and fed that into our listening process.” To view the full article and photographs click here.

item.title: CenturyLink Executives Enthusiastic About Canadian Expansion
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from IT In Canada Online
9/15/2014
CenturyLink Technology Solutions recently opened its third data centre in Canada and its second in the greater Toronto area. If the company has its way, TR3 in Markham will not be the last. Three executives from CenturyLink shared their thoughts on what the company has accomplished in Canada, where it stands now, and how it plans to grow in the True North. Jeff Von Deylen, president, CenturyLink, provided some background on the company’s history in Canada. “We acquired Fusepoint five years ago,” he said. Fusepoint was a managed IT colocations services provider. “We had clients in Canada that we couldn’t service, and Fusepoint had three facilities, customers and a distribution network,” Von Deylen added. “With the Fusepoint acquisition, we gained scale.” “Fusepoint was known for managed services,” added Ash Mathur, VP and country manager, Canada, CenturyLink. “It still is, but we’ve got an expanded portfolio.” The Canadian branch of CenturyLink offers customers colocation, cloud, managed hosting, managed security and managed networks solutions. After acquiring Fusepoint, CenturyLink gained a dedicated base of customers in Canada. Their base was so strong that demand grew for another data centre facility. CenturyLink operates a data centre in Vancouver and Mississauga, ON. David Meredith, SVP and global GM, CenturyLink, emphasized that Canada plays a strategic role in CenturyLink’s growth plans. He explained that the company has been considering expanding in the GTA. Customer demand rose sharply in the past 15 to 18 months. “We love Canada,” he remarked. “It was a high priority to get a data centre in Canada.” “Customer demand led to an acceleration [of the company’s plans to open a data centre],” Meredith commented. “Customers wanted more space, more power, more exposure to the cloud.” With those factors in place, it became a clear decision to open a new facility in the GTA. CenturyLink executives believe that the company’s data centres, especially TR3, meet a need in the Canadian market. “Businesses need agile, flexible services,” Von Deylen asserted. “We allow customers to buy cloud services when they need them and pay for it when they can. They can buy colocation services or dedicated servers through an automated system in an agile way.” Mathur reiterated Von Deylen’s statements: “Our value proposition is colo-managed cloud and the ability to scale globally.” Now that the data centre is open, CenturyLink’s goal is to educate potential customers about the benefits it offers. Mathur noted that CenturyLink is repositioning itself in the Canadian market in order to increase its customer base. “Repositioning is about helping customers understand our full suite of services and helping them understand the value we can provide them, such as thought leadership,” he stated. Von Deylen and Mathur acknowledged that repositioning has its challenges. “We’re going to work to be more well known by working with partners in the application layer,” CenturyLink’s president remarked. “It takes time to build a brand,” Mathur added. “We need to have more customer success stories and we need to build upon that success. Part of it is raising our significance and reach in Canada. We need to build our partner ecosystem, and we’re building our profile in the marketplace. It’s a long term journey.” What do the CenturyLink executives predict for the company’s future in Canada? “We’re focused on the GTA’s explosive growth,” Von Deylen commented. “We’re making the right decision.” He went on to say that TR3 will expand in phases. When asked where he sees CenturyLink going, Mathur responded, “I see us helping to educate the market and provide a suite of services.” He pointed out that it makes more sense for many businesses to let a trusted partner manage things such as their cloud, because it is better for them to focus on running their companies. “We’re going to look to continue to expand,” Meredith remarked. “Once we fill this building, we’re going to get another building. We can help Canadian customers who need to do business outside of Canada [because of CenturyLink’s 57 data centres across the globe]. Multi-national corporations outside of Canada now have the option to come into Canada. We’re just getting started,” Meredith concluded. View original article here.

item.title: Jeff Koons: Split-Rocker
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Rockefeller Center website
This summer, Jeff Koons's Split-Rocker makes its New York City debut at Rockefeller Center, to coincide with the opening of his retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Presented by Gagosian Gallery and organized by Public Art Fund and Tishman Speyer, Split-Rocker is a spectacular planted form that towers over 37 feet high and features over 50,000 flowering plants. It was first exhibited at Palais des Papes, Avignon in 2000; and subsequently at Château de Versailles (2008) and Fondation Beyeler (2012). It is also in the collection of the Glenstone private museum in Potomac, Maryland, where it has been on view since June of 2013. Consistent with Koons's persistent fascination with dichotomy and the in-between, the inspiration for Split-Rocker came when he decided to split and combine two similar but different toy rockers, a pony belonging to his son and a dinosaur (“Dino”). The slippage or "split" between the different halves of the heads gives an almost Cubist aspect to the composition. As the model was enlarged to the scale of a small house, the split became an opening, a profile, and a light shaft. In contrast to his legendary Puppy of 1992, which was presented by Public Art Fund at Rockefeller Center in the summer of 2000, Split-Rocker suggests the idea of a fantasy shelter. Whereas the singular form of Puppy is closed and sculptural, the combined form of Split-Rocker is architectural and hollow. To view the original article and photos click here. Photo: AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Jeff Koons' Whimsical 'Split-Rocker' Hits 30 Rock
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from New York Post
By: Barbara Hoffman
6/25/2014
Rockefeller Center has a new centerpiece — all 37 feet and 50,000 flowers of it. It’s Jeff Koons’ “Split-Rocker,” a mammoth topiary the Public Art Fund unveiled Wednesday at 30 Rock, right where the Christmas tree usually stands. Inspired by his son’s rocking horse and a toy dinosaur, Koons melded the two heads into one Picasso-like asymmetrical whole, with “handles” protruding from each side. Live flowers — begonias, geraniums, petunias and more — color the sculpture, watered by an irrigation system within its stainless-steel armature. If you’re feeling a sense of déjà vu, well, you should: Koons’ massive, flowery “Puppy” was unleashed on Rock Center 14 summers ago. But “Split-Rocker” is just the tip of Koons’ iceberg: His first New York museum retrospective opens Friday at the Whitney Museum of Art — five floors of the 59-year-old artist’s patented blend of innocence and erotica. Prepare to be amazed. To see the original article and photos click here. Photo: AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Noises Off
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Metropolis Magazine
In the beginning was the cubicle. And the cubicle was almost everywhere, and the cubicle held almost everyone, and it was good. Then there was the backlash, and the cubicle was destroyed, put aside, swept away in favor of the open plan, the endless span of space, floor, and ceiling—punctuated by the occasional column so that the roof wouldn’t collapse onto the floor plate—and everyone talked about collaboration, togetherness, synergy, randomness and happenstance. Renzo Piano designed a New York Times building with open stairways so writers and editors could (would have to) run into one another, and everyone remembered the always-ahead-of-the-curve Steve Jobs who, when he was running Pixar, asked for only two bathrooms in the whole Emeryville building, and insisted they be put on the ground floor lobby so that designers and renderers could (would have to) run into each other, and such was the office culture of the new millennium. And then there was the backlash to the backlash. Those writers wanted their own offices, and editors wanted privacy, and not everyone wanted to be running into people all the time, because not everyone was actually collaborating, even though their bosses and their bosses’ bosses said that they should, because collaboration, teamwork, and togetherness—these were the new workplace buzzwords. Until they weren’t. Until people realized that they were missing—as architect Ben Jacobson said in a Gensler sponsored panel on the need to create a balance between focus and collaboration—the concept of “parallel play,” i.e. people working next to each other, but not necessarily with each other. Until individuality came back, particularly in San Francisco in the tech scene, and particularly in the iconoclastic start-up tech scene, where people began to want something a little different. item.title: Working Like A Dog
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Washingtonian
By: Will Grunewald
6/10/2014

At MGAC, a construction-management firm, the rules are simple: no growling, no biting, no excessive barking. Petting, nuzzling, and fetching, on the other hand, are encouraged.

Most days, only humans occupy the company’s contemporary offices across the street from the Grand Hyatt in downtown DC. On Fridays, though, their dogs can join them.

Controller Elaine Maddalena owns Oscar, a beagle, as well as Gordon and Cosmo, German short-haired pointers. The three take turns visiting on Fridays, loping from desk to desk to greet familiar faces but mostly lounging at Maddalena’s side. “Everyone seems happy to have them around,” she says. “And the dogs love the attention.”

In response to employee requests, human-resources director Mollie O’Donnell devised Dog Fridays two years ago. The idea was to increase employee happiness and encourage positive work relationships and team building. The theory is that dogs make workplaces feel friendlier and less hierarchical—if your boss offers to walk your dog, it can soften the impact when he or she tells you to finish a report by the end of the day. “They bring a really nice change of atmosphere,” says CFO Matthew Anderson, owner of Gizmo, a Pembroke Welsh corgi. “If you have a meeting and you know it’s going to be tense, you can just bring him in and it changes the dynamic.”

The soft and fuzzy benefits of workplace pets are borne out by numbers. In 2005, researchers from the Center for Human-Animal Interaction at Virginia Commonwealth University found—using blood and saliva samples—that therapy-dog sessions reduced levels of stress-related hormones in health-care workers. In 2012, they followed up by studying self-reported stress levels in office workers. In employees who didn’t bring dogs to work, stress rose throughout the workday. In those who did bring dogs, stress dropped as the day went on.

Still, only 5 percent of US companies allow pets, according to the Society for Human Resource Management. Lisa Orndorff, who heads employee relations and engagement there, says workplace pets aren’t always a good fit. Companies have to account for allergies or phobias, and in industries such as food service and manufacturing, the presence of pets would be neither safe nor practical.

Orndorff says companies that decide to allow pets need to establish rules about animal behavior and hygiene and make sure animals are up to date on immunizations. Also, though owners are generally responsible for damage or injury caused by their pets, companies should consult with legal counsel to clarify potential liability.

At Anthony Wilder Design/Build, an architecture firm in Cabin John, owners and employees embrace the pet-friendly ethos. The renovated red-brick firehouse is specially equipped to cater to canines: Cubicles are fitted with baby gates to keep dogs in place, file cabinets are filled with dog chow, and there’s a cleanup-bag dispenser outside. “We know they bring us joy and happiness and help us be more productive at work, so we make accommodations for them,” says Elizabeth Wilder. She and husband Anthony co-own the company and always bring their two rottweiler mixes, Tank and Izzy, to work.

Dogs are allowed every day, and most days there are four or five. Some employees like to take their dogs running on the nearby C&O Canal towpath during breaks. Others enjoy strolling around the neighborhood. Marketing director Danielle Frye has been bringing Lily, a rottweiler/German-shepherd mix, almost every day since she got her as a puppy four years ago. “If you’re having a stressful moment,” she says, “it’s really nice to hang out with a dog.”

Illustration by Britt Spencer

item.title: Crafting Better Outcomes
item.dc:creator: manderson
item.content:encoded:
As an owner’s representative, I’ve had the pleasure of working alongside many great leaders and brilliant business minds. I’ve represented them, debated with them, vetted them as project partners, and celebrated with them after a collective job well done. Every business is run differently, based on their own unique business model, core values, and culture; and to each their own I say. But every exposure to another’s business has taught me something about my own. I’ve found these observations in the field to be invaluable learning opportunities that continue to impact how we run, and market, our business.

THERE’S POWER IN ALIGNMENT

At a recent business meeting, I witnessed a presentation about Southwest Airlines. Southwest’s mission statement is simple: “wheels up.” When the airplane is on the ground, it is losing money. When the airplane is in the air, it is making money. Everyone at Southwest understands that, and they’ve adopted the “wheels up” mentality as their collective battle cry. I was amazed at the simplicity of this powerful statement. In two simple words, Southwest is able to align and articulate what drives both their business and their culture. A defined mission creates clarity in any business, even if it’s not as elegantly spoken as Southwest’s. Recently I was interviewing for a project with a large Pacific Northwest retailer we all admire. They began the meeting with this simple statement: “We sell shirts. If this project doesn’t help us sell more shirts, it is not aligned with our goals, and we won’t do it.” Simple and to the point. Though they surely have a vibrant corporate culture and artfully crafted mission, vision, and core values, they’re able to uphold them while maintaining laser focus on the bottom line. Every decision they make is based on the answer to one question: Will this help us sell more shirts?

IDENTIFYING YOUR CRAFT

Despite advancements in technology, the business of building still belongs to the craftsmen. I have the privilege to regularly observe craftsmen practicing their trade. Working on one of our projects, in my opinion, are the best stone masons and finish carpenters in Washington, DC. Watching them work, make mistakes, solve problems, cut and fit materials, and get the best out of the design and materials provided to them in the time they have to do it is in one word, remarkable. One quickly realizes that these men and women practice more than a trade, they practice a craft. Creatively getting more out of a situation than seems likely, or even possible. They bend materials, design, and adjoining work into something better than the sum of its parts. They produce the 110% outcome.

MY MOMENT OF ZEN

Reflecting upon these three examples of very different, yet very impressive businesses, it suddenly seemed obvious to me that MGAC’s mission has been, is today, and must continue to be “better outcomes.” For us, outcomes can be reducing the cost of a project, or even finding the right contractors, suppliers and subcontractors to yield an extraordinary project. Outcomes can have multiple layers, from timeliness of delivery, to the continuity of a client’s business operation, to proper deployment of cutting edge technologies. They can include choosing what and how much to build, or not to build at all. Our craft is combining intelligence and experience with creative thinking to yield better outcomes. The facilities, design, and construction world is full of examples of failed projects. I often think design and construction efforts are like mountain climbing (like watching construction, another of my pastimes), take your eyes off what is going on, where you are going, and how you are getting there for even a moment, and things can go off the rails very quickly. Better outcomes. Maybe not as catchy as “wheels up,” but we’re just as passionate about our outcomes as they are. Anything less, and we have not practiced our craft.

item.title: Can Net Zero Find A Home In Commercial Real Estate?
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
On Wednesday, July 22nd, I attended the CREW Maryland Suburban tour of the National Institute of Standards and Technology’s (NIST) Net Zero Energy Residential Test Facility (NZERTF) with a client. This particular client is exploring the option to renovate an existing commercial office building achieve Net Zero energy and water, and we wanted to see firsthand the strategies that NIST employed to make their design successful. What from the outside looked like a standard suburban home, was anything but, and opened our eyes to the potential of Net Zero Energy becoming a part of our every day lives. Our tour guide, Dr. Hunter Fanney, the NIST engineer that has guided the project from conception through design and construction to actual real time data success, was a wealth of information. It was an exceptional tour that allowed us to walk all corners of the house and see the equipment in operation and to understand how it works.

ENCOURAGING PROGRESS

The NIST “virtual” family of four moved into the NZERTF home in June 2013. NIST collects and tracks over 400 data points per minute based on how the “family” is programmed to use the home. The results after the first year, June 2013 to June 2014, prove that the family saved over $4,500 in electric bills and even returned 4,200 kilowatt hours back to the grid for a refund of $570. Even more encouraging, it is expected that they will improve and benefit from even greater savings this year over last. With one exception, NIST used all American-made equipment in the house, which was encouraging to our client. It proves the technology exists in this country to go beyond code compliant energy efficiency to not only achieve Net Zero energy, but to actually return power to the grid. Part of the strategy’s success included angling the solar array on the south face of the house to a perfect angle of 38%, the same as the geographical latitude of the home/building location, to maximize production from the panels (who knew?!). They also installed three different geothermal systems which are being tested and compared for efficiency.

THE FUTURE CHALLENGE

NIST has modeled the cost difference between their NZERTF house and one that would meet the Maryland residential energy code based on 2012 IECC (which was updated in January 2015). The adjusted cost to build the NZERTF house (without land) was $656,000 compared to the 2012 code model at $493,000 for a premium of $163,000. This represents a 33% increase in initial cost with an annual cost savings of $4,500, resulting in a 36-year payback period. Of course this calculation does not include the potential federal, state, and utility incentives that might help to offset some of the initial construction cost premiums, such as Solar Renewable Energy Credits (SRECs). There are also the non-monetary benefits to the consumer involved in delivering a more comfortable and healthier environment. In short, the cost to build the NSERTF house on the NIST campus, to its exact specifications, is not yet a financially viable and repeatable model for the typical consumer. A larger scale development of similar houses will require a public awareness with proven and documented statistics on not just why it’s the right thing to do, but how the consumer will benefit and save long-term based on the increased initial investment. If the public is informed and asks for Net Zero, which we’re already starting to see happen, the builders will be incentivized to build it. And if the government regulates it, manufacturers will find a way to build it efficiently and economically. The consumer will want to know the benefits of the resale of a Net Zero home, and right now the market rate and assessment benefits have not yet been proven in the market. Time will tell how the market will respond when the facts are available.

WHAT THIS MEANS TO THE COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE INDUSTRY

Right now, many commercial developers are only looking to meet LEED standards and most are operating under a short-term ownership strategy. This differs drastically from the residential consumer, who is typically a longer-term investor. But that doesn’t mean the commercial real estate world can’t learn from these smaller scale efforts. Net Zero energy efficiency design strategies save real operating dollars and create a healthier building. This translates to high-performing building and a healthier environment for the tenants working in the building, ultimately supporting higher revenues and faster leasing and sales. These benefits, plus the alignment with their corporate mission are what is driving our current client to explore the option, and I’m excited to take this journey with them. Educated consumers are going to demand Net Zero in the future. Smart owners of commercial buildings should position themselves to be on the forefront of this movement, capitalizing on the fact that Net Zero design strategies will be particularly attractive to the long-term owner or investor.

HOPE FOR CHANGE

NIST’s work has proved that the technology exists to build a building, on the scale of a home, using no more electricity than it produces. They’ve also created a viable system to track and produce real time data on various strategies and make it available to the world. As we know, information is power (pun intended) and as consumers and owners become more educated and sophisticated, equipment manufacturers, developers, and homebuilders will be forced to comply with the demand. The hard work continues. NIST did not include Net Zero water into their design, and those strategies need the same level of proven track record and cost metrics to make headway in the marketplace. The good news, though, is that it is possible. We can design and build in a sustainable way, using the free power of the sun and earth to do so, and clients are starting to take notice.
item.excerpt:encoded: Net Zero homes are gaining traction in the market, and my recent tour of the National Institute of Standards and Technology’s (NIST) Net Zero Energy Residential Test Facility (NZERTF) with CREW Maryland Suburban showed just how real the benefits can be. There's still a long way to go until Net Zero becomes the standard, but we can design and build in a sustainable way, using the free power of the sun and earth to do so, and clients are starting to take notice.

item.title: Featured Philanthropy: Calvary Women's Services
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Since its inception, part of MGAC’s mission has been to give back to the local communities in which we work. Regardless of the cause, a commitment to making a meaningful impact on the lives of others is a core part of who we are. Over the years, we have worked with countless organizations, forming long-term relationships and donating our time, talent and resources to helping advance their missions and expand their impact. Today we kick off our Featured Philanthropy series as another way of helping to spread the word about these amazing organizations. In that spirit, we bring you the first in this series, featuring an organization that is very near and dear to our collective heart, Calvary Women’s Services. We sat down with Heather Laing, Development Director with Calvary Women’s Services, to learn more about the organization, where it’s been, and where it’s going. Here’s what she had to say about the future of this year’s honorable mention winner of The Washington Post Award for Excellence in Nonprofit Management.

Q: WHO ARE THE WOMEN OF CALVARY WOMEN’S SERVICES?

A: Women who come to Calvary Women’s Services are homeless. They may be survivors of domestic violence, they may live with mental illnesses, they may be in recovery from addiction, or they may have other health issues. But they want to change their lives, and we give them the means and support to do that. Through our programs women set and achieve their own goals, with a focus on building skills for stronger futures. We know our programs work: every five days a woman moves from Calvary into her own home.

Q: WHAT BROUGHT YOU TO CALVARY WOMEN’S SERVICES?

A: I came to Calvary Women’s Services so that I could put the skills I have in resource development to work making a difference for women. I get to see women transform their lives and to know that my work helped make that possible. It’s also a real pleasure to be able to connect supporters and volunteers to Calvary – to help people find ways to give back that are meaningful for them and to see the impact and the joy that creates for everyone involved.

Q: HOW HAVE YOU SEEN CALVARY WOMEN’S SERVICES EVOLVE SINCE YOU’VE BEEN WITH THEM?

A: Over the 13 years I have been at Calvary Women’s Services it has grown significantly. We have added a third housing program, expanded our education and mental health services, and launched a job placement program. Most notably, four years ago we purchased a new building on Good Hope Road in DC’s Anacostia neighborhood, and with support from MGAC and other partners, we were able to renovate that to serve more women and expand our services. A vacant building was transformed into a beautiful new home for 45 women with space for all of our health, education and employment programs. We moved in two years ago, and the difference it has made is amazing.

Q: WHAT’S YOUR MOST MEMORABLE CALVARY WOMEN’S SERVICES SUCCESS STORY?

A: One woman who comes to mind is Jill, who was a survivor of domestic violence and who came to Calvary Women’s Services when she was early in recovery from addiction. She had dropped out of school in sixth grade and had never been able to secure employment that enabled her to support herself. When she moved from our previous location in Chinatown to our new home on Good Hope Road, she was blown away by new space. She told us how much it felt like a home, and she took advantage of the new programs we were able to offer. Jill took all kinds of classes, attended daily relapse prevention meetings and learned practical skills like how to open a bank account. Now she lives in an apartment in our Sister Circle housing. She has maintained her sobriety and this summer will complete her GED program. It’s always amazing to me to see women achieve goals like this, things that may have seemed impossible at one time. Women have the gifts and strengths to build on, and Calvary provides the personal support and resources that make it possible.

Q: WHAT WILL THE NEXT TWO YEARS LOOK LIKE AT CALVARY WOMEN’S SERVICES?

A: Over the next two years, Calvary Women’s Services will continue to grow our programs that we know women need and that we know will have a real and lasting impact on our community. We will expand our job placement program, Step Up DC, connecting more women with jobs. We will continue to grow our mental health services. We are also planning for additional permanent, affordable housing for women, following the model of our successful Sister Circle program. To do all of this, we will create new opportunities for volunteers and supporters to get involved and make a difference.

Q: CALVARY WOMEN’S SERVICES JUST RAISED OVER $300,000 AT THIS YEAR’S HOPE AWARDS DINNER. HOW ARE THOSE DONATION DOLLARS PUT TO USE TO HELP THE WOMEN OF CALVARY?

A: The Hope Awards Dinner, for which MGAC was the presenting sponsor, supports Calvary’s housing, health, education and employment programs that women use to change their lives. The event brings together community and business leaders to celebrate hope – which is what these programs provide. We put those donation dollars to work: providing women a safe place to live, making home-cooked meals, offering skills building classes, and much more. When people support Calvary – through the Hope Awards Dinner or otherwise – they can be confident that what they give matters and will be used well.

Q: HOW CAN PEOPLE SUPPORT OR GET INVOLVED WITH CALVARY WOMEN’S SERVICES?

A: One of the things I love about Calvary Women’s Services is the fantastic community of people who make all of this happen. There are opportunities to offer financial support or to donate items from our current wish list. For people who prefer to be more hands on, we have a family of over 350 volunteers. We are always happy to have new folks joins us to do everything from serving meals to leading classes to spending the night with us. Heather Laing became Calvary Women’s Services’ first Development Director in 2002. As Development Director, Heather develops and executes an annual fundraising plan, cultivates and solicits major donors, manages communications and marketing and supervises a staff of three fundraising professionals. She has managed the growth of the fundraising program through three significant program expansion projects and a capital campaign. Under her leadership Calvary has increased annual revenue from major donors, fundraising events and corporations by over 100% each. Meet the rest of the staff and board behind Calvary Women's Services. Interested in learning more about Calvary Women’s Services or how you can get involved? Visit their website, connect with them on Facebook and Twitter, or give them a call directly to speak with the volunteer coordinator. All photos are courtesy of Calvary Women's Services Flikr page.

item.title: Six Key Takeaways from HD Expo 2015
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Last month I joined MGAC colleague Jerry Walters and more than 8,000 hospitality professionals, leaders, and experts in Las Vegas for this year’s Hospitality Design Expo and Conference. A three-day event full of exhibits, continuing education and networking, we go for one reason – to hear firsthand from clients and partners where the hospitality industry is moving. With almost 30 sessions making up the conference program, we chose to stick with roundtable and panel formats that allowed us to speak directly with our clients, the owners, about the trends and issues that matter most to them. Here are six key themes that we took away from those discussions.

THE TALENT GAP IS REAL, AND SO ARE THE CONSEQUENCES

A major thread that seemed to run through discussions across the Expo is the shrinking talent pool and the impact it is having on the industry. This is especially true in the design fields where young talent are moving away from the industry right as they are gaining the experience to achieve valuable specialization. The challenge on everyone’s mind is how the industry can motivate retention in a world with long hours and admittedly low pay. Within our own profession, project management, owner’s expressed a lack of depth when it comes to experience. They are seeing strong junior PMs, as well as trusted experts in upper management, but the absence of middle management has created an atmosphere where existing talent is spread too thin, causing projects to fall into the weeds too easily. Owners themselves have their own challenges to deal with as they struggle with the pressure of getting projects done within compressed schedules. The lack of talent is impacting their ability to effectively meet project milestones as less experience combines with quick turnaround to result in costly project complications. Even when issues are identified, teams don’t seem to have the experience or sufficient resources to manage the complex challenges.

DISCUSSION OF GREEN WAS LEAN

As we reflected on topics that stood out, it dawned on us that one key theme was noticeably missing. Still a hot topic in the program schedule, sustainability seems to take a back seat in our conversations with the owners. Now this isn’t to say that there aren’t owners out there doing it and making it a priority. It just didn’t receive the focus that one might expect at a conference meant to discuss trends in the building industry. One reason may be that hoteliers aren’t seeing the financial value of seeking LEED certification in their properties just yet. But we don’t see that lasting long. With many companies and professional organizations taking a stand on sustainability as a part of their core values and corporate responsibility programs, we see the hotel industry needing to catch up in order to attract and retain their business. This is especially true when it comes to government organizations, whose conferences, meetings, and travel account for a significant chunk of the hospitality industry.

THE BIG BRANDS ARE BECOMING POLARIZED

Obvious throughout the three days of conversations was the significant growth being experienced across the extended-stay and limited-service markets. An unfortunate result of this new trend will be the increased polarization of big brands like Starwood, Hilton, Marriott and Wyndham, who seek to have a presence across the variety of price points in the market. With money seemingly filtering to their high- and low-end properties, we’re left wondering what will become of the stagnating mid-price full service brands? Is this the beginning of the end for these travel mainstays? Our guess is no, but it will be interesting to see how they continue to compete for business while investment funds are flowing elsewhere.

SECONDARY MARKET CITIES ARE ON THE RISE

Hellooooo…Denver? That’s right, cities like Denver, Philadelphia, Nashville, and Houston are some of the hottest cities for hospitality development right now. The discussion of secondary market resurgence seems to be a direct result of these gateway cities working to reinvent themselves to attract a new generation of business and tourism to their area. Appealing for their uniqueness and authenticity, these markets are now playing catch up when it comes to having the capacity to support the influx of visitors. A particular challenge for the hospitality industry seems to be the lack of availability of existing buildings that can be converted into hotels. According to owners, the only way to serve these markets moving forward is to build. This will present a unique challenge for developers, and the cities themselves, as they attempt to balance new development with the authenticity that drew investment in the first place.

GROUND-UP DEVELOPMENT IS BACK

A year ago, no one was talking about ground-up development. But this year we noticed owners were not only talking about it, they were excited. According to owners, finding a deal on existing and well-stabilized hotels has become increasingly difficult, and those properties they can find typically have poorly maintained infrastructure that will cause complications down the road. The high cost of bringing the property back up to par is no longer worth the investment, especially for those owners who are trying to get ahead of the curve. With the average daily rate on the rise, it now makes better financial sense for owners to turn to new development to expand their existing portfolios.

TECHNOLOGY STILL NEEDS TO PROVE ITSELF

Another topic that we expected to play a larger role in discussions was technology. A hot topic across industry publications, it doesn’t seem that innovations such as 4K television panels and robot butlers have earned a seat at the table just yet. A big reason is that owners are waiting for new technologies to be thoroughly tested and vetted before they risk investing. We can certainly sympathize. Discussions with our own clients reveal that they don’t know what to implement, how far to go, or how much to invest while available technologies continue to change at a break-neck pace. For now, it seems that most are investing in improving the customer experience through technology upgrades and increased convenience and connectivity through free WiFi and the addition of plugs and charging stations across the entire property. We had a great time at HD Expo 2015 and learned a lot about how we can better serve and represent our clients in the upcoming year. Hope to see you there next year!

item.title: Can Fiduciary Duty Extend to A/E/C Relationships?
item.dc:creator: manderson
item.content:encoded:
Should architects, engineers, and construction professionals be held to the same standard of care as doctors and attorneys? The City of Victorville says yes, and they have the settlement to prove it. Acting solely in another party’s interest. That’s how Cornell University’s Legal Information Institute defines the term fiduciary duty. Doctors and lawyers are subject to it every day as they serve the general public who undeniably depend on the knowledge and experience of these professionals to represent their best interest in a time of need. Those who abuse that power, to put their own interests above those of their patient or client, are subject to litigation and potential loss of their ability to practice their chosen profession.

SETTING PRECEDENT

I recently read an article published in the New York Law Journal by the law firm WilmerHale. The article, “Fiduciary Duty Claims Against Construction and Design Professionals,” indicates that courts have held that this similar expectation, one of fiduciary duty, can be construed to exist between, in their specific example, an engineering firm and its client. The cited case, City of Victorville v. Carter & Burgess, sought reparations “for the costs of the unfinished job,” and “a breach of fiduciary duty claim for Carter & Burgess’ alleged poor-quality designs and failure to supervise the project’s development.” The case resulted in a $52 million settlement for the City of Victorville. We recently worked on the correction of a rather significant "bad project" where lack of complete design documentation, coupled with a high degree of owner directed change, and further complicated by an immovable completion date resulted in a poorly coordinated construction effort. The result was the delivery of an unsafe, incomplete, and poor quality product. Throughout the project, and the resulting mediation, the term "standard of care" was thrown about frequently.

FIDUCIARY DUTY V. STANDARD OF CARE

This begs the question, where do we draw the line between standard of care and fiduciary duty in the design and construction industry? In short, standard of care can be summarized to mean that a firm in question performed to the level of competency found by similar firms on similar projects in similar locations. Architects, engineers, and contractors building single story wood framed houses have a standard of care different from architects, engineers and contractors delivering dense urban high rises, or complex data centers. The skills, care and knowledge base required are inherently different. A fiduciary responsibility is altogether above normal and accepted standard of care, regardless of the complexity of a particular project. And though precedent has been set, City of Victorville v. Carter & Burgess will most likely remain an exception to the rule for now.

BUYER BEWARE

A client seeking to procure design and construction services should be aware that the industry as a whole presumes standard of care is the accepted measure, and not fiduciary responsibility. As professional services firms, our ability to provide quality services that meets our clients’ needs are of the utmost importance to ongoing success as a business. However, the definition of quality and approach to customer service differ from firm to firm and are influenced more by a company’s ethical standards than their standard contracts. Unfortunately, not all contractors, architects, engineers, project managers, or real estate advisors/brokers work from the same set of ethical standards. Smart purchasers of these services take this into account, and make informed decisions based on the motivations and reputations of the companies under consideration. When it comes to these qualifiers, we are not all equal. Just ask the City of Victorville.

item.title: MGAC Remembers A. James Clark
item.dc:creator: manderson
item.content:encoded:
Earlier this week, Washington lost a great business leader who was instrumental in transforming the landscape of our nation’s capital and whose national construction firm made us all better at what we do. A. James Clark was a recognized icon in business and construction, and built an impressive company with committed employees and devoted clients.
Beginning as a concrete layout engineer with George Hyman Construction, Mr. Clark went on to transform the company into one of the nation’s largest construction companies, forever changing the course of general contracting and construction. Mr. Clark was an entrepreneur operating in a large business. In the 1970s and 1980s, Clark was at the forefront of changing Washington real estate and construction from family businesses and largely unionized construction into what it is today. Mr. Clark started Omni Construction in the early 1980s, which drove the construction industry to largely open and merit shop construction. Companies which dominated construction at the time included Blake Construction, Volpe, and Charles H. Tompkins. These companies are gone, or have largely disappeared from this transformation.
Omni brought new faces, new practices, and followed booming growth from Washington’s family developers, including Oliver Carr Company and John Akridge. This transformation of the industry moved general contracting away from “builder” contractors to the Omni model of subcontracting, helping to further companies such as Miller & Long. Omni and Hyman were eventually morphed into the single entity of Clark Construction and construction in Washington was never the same. And it never will be. Despite the firm’s exceptional growth, Mr. Clark always invested in Washington, DC and he never forgot his local roots as seen through the firm’s many philanthropic engagements in our city and the greater metro area.
MGAC has been fortunate to work with Clark Construction and their subsidiary companies on many occasions, from interiors projects to base buildings. We are proud of our many years of partnership which have resulted in memorable projects throughout the DC metro area, from our first projects as a company to the exciting work we do today.
The Clark legacy will foster project-based teams that come together to problem-solve, causing real momentum that rolls projects to completion. Mr. Clark left an exceptional legacy – from the bricks and mortar projects located on almost every street corner across DC to his savvy business sense and benevolence in the local community.
We thank him and his firm for their contribution to our industry and our society. One of our true greats will be greatly missed.
item.excerpt:encoded: Earlier this week, Washington lost a great business leader who was instrumental in transforming the landscape of our nation’s capital and whose national construction firm made us all better at what we do. A. James Clark was a recognized icon in business and construction, and built an impressive company with committed employees and devoted clients.

item.title: Isabel Bader Centre Architect Wins Award
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from The Whig-Standard
6/7/2015
The Isabel Bader Centre for the Performing Arts received the first Ontario Association of Architects Lieutenant-Governor's Award at the association's Centre of Excellence awards in Hamilton last month. Accepting the award was the architect of the building, Ottawa-based N45 Architecture. Lt.-Gov. Elizabeth Dowdeswell presented the award, the highest honour given out for architectural work in Ontario. The event showcased the best in architectural design and innovation by Ontario architects. Twenty buildings designed by Ontario architects were also given Design Excellence awards. Some of those buildings are in Toronto, St. Petersburg (Russia), Georgian Bay, Sudbury, Sarnia, Oakville, Port Hope and Surrey, B.C. The Isabel, which opened last year at 390 King St. West, next to the Tett Centre for Creativity and Learning, is a $72 million, 80,000-square-foot performance hall, which also acts as learning space for Queen's University students from the theatre, music, film and media faculties. The building features state-of-the-art ventilation, acoustics and soundproofing -- including two-foot-thick walls around the performance hall. The architects preserved and revitalized original brick and wood from the historic structures previously located on the site, maintaining the architectural significance of the building. item.title: Law Firms Try to Shake up Old Image with New, Bold Art Made Specially for Them
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from The Washington Post
2/9/2015
When Australian artist Jonathan Zawada was putting the finishing touches this month on a 36-foot-by-12-foot acrylic painting that blends the natural landscape of mountains with the pixelated virtual reality of the video game world, it was not at his Los Angeles studio. And the work will not be featured in an art gallery. Zawada was painting a wall inside the downtown Washington offices of Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman, the global law firm that commissioned his work for the firm’s new office. The yet-to-be-named artwork, which is made entirely of brightly colored triangles, takes up a wall of Pillsbury’s first-floor conference center and can be seen from the street through the building’s floor-to-ceiling glass windows. It is the first time that Zawada, whose artwork is typically in private collections, has created a piece for a private company. Corporate law firms, which for many evoke images of stuffy oil paintings and oriental rugs, are increasingly home to never-before-seen works by artists who trade in light installations, lithographs and metal sculptures. The trend is a stark contrast from a generation ago, when law partners were known to amass expensive art collections. Of course, many law firms still maintain expansive, curated collections. But increasingly, law firms are commissioning artists to create tailor-made pieces that fit the more modern architecture and aesthetics of the firms. The phenomenon is playing out at law firms across the city. The main lobby of Covington & Burling, the District’s largest law firm and anchor tenant at CityCenter DC, will soon be home to Venezuelan artist Carlos Cruz-Diez’s first major installation in the Northeast, which will incorporate natural light coming through the building’s glass walls. McDermott Will & Emery, which in 2013 relocated its Washington office to a newly designed building on Capitol Hill, commissioned two pieces — a series of 17 lithographs by New York City-based artist Peter Coffin and a 20-foot LED lightbox by Spencer Finch, the Brooklyn-based artist who was later selected to offer the only artwork commissioned for the National September 11 Memorial Museum. The lightbox Finch created for McDermott, “Summer Afternoon, 1863, Washington, D.C.,” re-creates the afternoon sunlight at the street corner in Washington where Walt Whitman and Abraham Lincoln passed each other regularly during the summer of 1863. item.title: John Whitehead, Who Led Effort to Rebuild After 9/11, Dies at 92
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from New York Times
2/9/2015

John C. Whitehead, for decades one of New York’s most prominent citizens, a veteran of D-Day who capped a lauded career on Wall Street and in the State Department by shepherding the first years of the city’s fractious effort to rebuild after the 2001 terrorist attacks, died on Saturday at his home in New York. He was 92.

Haverford College, from which he had graduated and where he served on the board of managers, announced his death, saying the cause was cancer.

The columnist Liz Smith once called Mr. Whitehead the “chairman of the establishment.” He helped pilot Goldman Sachs to the forefront of investment banking and led the boards of Harvard, the Asia Society and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, among other institutions. As deputy secretary of state in the Reagan administration, he helped wean the countries of Eastern Europe from the Soviet Union.

His connections were so broad, he said, that in 10 minutes of conversation with “just about anyone,” he could find “a mutual friend we both know well.”

Mr. Whitehead’s stiffest challenge came as he neared his 80th birthday, when Gov. George E. Pataki of New York asked him to be chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. A state entity, it was given the mandate to rebuild the shattered site of the World Trade Center towers and revitalize downtown Manhattan.

In his autobiography, “A Life in Leadership: From D-Day to Ground Zero” (2005), Mr. Whitehead recalled replying that he would be ancient by the end of the effort.

“I don’t think you want me down there a decade from now in my wheelchair, pointing my cane at some building and saying, ‘I’ll put this building here, not there,’ ” he wrote.

He decided to turn down what was then his city’s, if not his country’s, most momentous job. Then he changed his mind. As he had many times, he felt a call to duty. He concluded that he had no right to say no.

“When the fireman hears the bell go off, he’s off to the fire,” Mr. Whitehead wrote. “And I guess I heard the bell.”

The reality of the decision hit him after the news conference where Mr. Pataki announced his appointment. Mr. Whitehead had no staff, no money, not even an office.

“That moment in the car was probably the loneliest moment of my entire life,” he wrote.

For five years, Mr. Whitehead juggled the competing interests of local residents, business leaders, cultural groups, the city, two states, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and families of the victims of the attacks. His agency conducted 200 public hearings and produced a master plan that changed greatly but endured.

Click here to read full article.

item.title: Max Impact: TWC Residential Video Sub Losses Dropped 75% in Q4 to 38K
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from Fierce Cable
1/30/2015

Time Warner Cable (NYSE: TWC) reported strong fourth-quarter residential subscriber metrics, highlighted by residential video declines that slowed by 75 percent to just 38,000.

Overall, TWC gained 54,000 residential customers in Q4, adding 168,000 residential high-speed Internet subscribers and 295,000 residential voice subs during the period, the latter being an all-time fourth-quarter mark for the company. The MSO also added 273,000 triple play customers, another Q4 best. New York-based TWC reported a revenue increase of 3.8 percent for the quarter to $579 million and narrowly missing investor forecasts on earnings per share of $2.09. TWC CEO Rob Marcus attributed the increased subscriber relationships to improvements in technology and customer service, reporting an 18 percent decline in customer trouble calls in Q4. TWC, for example, finished rollouts of DOCSIS 3.0-based Maxx broadband services in New York and Los Angeles during the quarter. With both AT&T (NYSE: T) and Verizon (NYSE: VZ) reporting decreases in video subscriber growth, Marcus conceded that TWC was more competitive in markets in which TWC has overlap with the telecoms. "We did do well in U-verse markets. We did well in FiOS markets, too," he said. Marcus delivered his Q4 address to investors Thursday as numerous investors began to ponder the increasingly real possibility that the Federal Communications Commission ultimately will reject TWC's $45 billion purchase by Comcast (NASDAQ: CMCSA). Marcus, however, would not indulge this speculation, noting that TWC is still operating as if the merger is an inevitability. The company did not deliver full 2015 guidance or a dividend--as it usually does in its Q4 report--in preparation of a deal closure it still expects to occur in the first half of this year. When asked about Dish Network's (NASDAQ: DISH) disruptive new OTT service, Sling TV, Marcus struck a dismissive tone that mirrored that expressed by Charter Communications (NASDAQ: CHTR) during its Q3 call last spring--TWC supports the notion of stripped-down programming bundles, but it believes its base content packages offer customers more and render Sling TV not so special. While coy, Marcus was more effusive when the subject of Cablevision's new Wi-Fi calling service, Freewheel, was brought up. "Using Wi-fi as a component of a voice product is pretty intriguing," he said. Full article located here.

item.title: Welcome to The Washington Post's 2015 Roundup of Top Workplaces
item.dc:creator: MGAC Marketing
item.content:encoded:
Sourced from The Washington Post
6/19/2015
Welcome to The Washington Post’s annual roundup of Top Workplaces, our attempt to identify the best places to work in greater Washington. The 150 organizations that made the cut this year scored the highest all-around when we surveyed their employees. We asked people to evaluate their employers on a host of factors, including the quality of leadership, pay and benefit practices, and work-life balance issues. [Meet the 150 companies that employees love the most in the D.C. area] Funny thing, it is often not the pay and perks that push companies to the top of our list. Research by our partner in this project, the employee survey firm WorkplaceDynamics, found that while just more than half of all respondents said pay and benefits were important factors in how they viewed their employers, far more, over 75 percent, said it was important to feel connected to their workplace through meaningful work and the belief that their company is moving in the right direction. A whopping 71 percent of the people surveyed at our Top Workplaces said they genuinely feel appreciated by their employer. Two-thirds feel confident about their future, and almost as many expressed confidence in the leadership. Take a look at the place you work. Do you buy in to where the organization is heading and how it is getting there? It’s our hope this report provokes a wider conversation on just what makes an organization stand out. Calvary Women’s Services will host the 14th Annual Hope Awards Dinner on May 14, 2015 to honor local leaders and celebrate the accomplishments of women who are overcoming homelessness. All proceeds from the event will support Calvary’s housing, health, education and employment programs for homeless women in Washington. The Hope Awards Dinner is Calvary’s largest fundraising event of the year, and more than 300 guests are anticipated to be in attendance. Rosie Allen-Herring, president and chief executive officer of United Way of the National Capital Area (United Way NCA), will be presented with the Hope Award. She has more than 20 years of experience in strategic leadership, public and private partnership development, corporate philanthropy and community investment. She oversees United Way NCA’s efforts to help all individuals lead better lives through initiatives that support quality education, financial stability and good health. Allen-Herring will join a distinguished list of past honorees who have received the Hope Award, including Katie Couric, Sheila Johnson, Diane Rehm and Judy Smith. The Hope Awards Dinner will be held in the Atrium Ballroom of the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center. The event begins at 6 p.m. with a cocktail reception and silent auction, followed by dinner, live auction and award presentation. Tickets and sponsorships for the Hope Awards Dinner may be purchased at http://bit.ly/2015hope. MGAC is the Presenting Sponsor of the 14th Annual Hope Awards Dinner. The event is sponsored by Battelle Memorial Institute, Performix Consulting and Walmart, in addition to many other organizations and individuals.
